title-group.article-title: Exposure to and Understanding of Technical Terms in Informed Consent Forms for Biomedical Research

article-meta.aff: 1College of Nursing, Pusan National University, Yangsan, South Korea
2Pharmacy Department, Pusan National University, Yangsan Hospital, Yangsan, South Korea
3Department of Family Medicine, Pusan National University, Yangsan Hospital, Yangsan, South Korea
4Department of Pharmacology, Inje University College of Medicine, Gimhae, South Korea, and Department of Clinical Pharmacology, Busan Paik Hospital, Busan, South Korea

author-notes.corresp: Ihn Sook Jeong, RN, PhD, College of Nursing, Pusan National University, Beomeo-ri Mulgeum-eup, Yangsan-si, Gyeongnam, Republic of Korea, 626-870 (email: jeongis@pusan.ac.kr).

abstract.p: This cross-sectional survey with 432 patients and 158 nurses investigated the exposure to and understanding of technical terms used in informed consent forms (ICFs) for biomedical research in the Republic of Korea. The percentage of positive responses, when asked if ever exposed to the study-related terms, ranged from 4.9% to 80.8% for patients and 22.8% to 99.4% for nurses. The term phase III was least recognized by both patients and nurses. The percentage of positive responses to “understanding the study-related terms well” ranged from 0.9% to 56.2% for patients and 5.1% to 70.9% for nurses. The average number of positive respondents, when asked if they understood each term well, statistically differed by age group, education, and exposure to clinical research for patients and by education and exposure to biomedical research for nurses. The low level of understanding of technical terms in ICFs should be improved by ensuring that sufficient explanations are provided to patients while obtaining informed consent and by replacing terms with more common and easily understandable words.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Informed consent is one of the most important concepts as an ethical and legal standard to protect subjects participating in biomedical research. Since the advent of the Nuremberg Code, 1 which enshrined the ethical principles concerning modern biomedical research and highlighted the fundamental right of subjects to informed consent, many ethical principles 2
–5 have been recommended to sufficiently provide information to subjects and to obtain their consent based on adequate and freely offered explanations. In particular, the Belmont Report considered informed consent a crucial way to protect subjects participating in biomedical research and emphasized that effective informed consent requires sufficient information disclosure, proper comprehension of provided information, and voluntary consent.

Section 4.8.6 of the International Conference on Harmonization (ICH) guidelines suggests that the terms used in informed consent should be as nontechnical as practical and understandable to the subject. 4 Furthermore, the US National Institutes of Health also has a specific criterion that the readability level, measured by the Flesch-Kincaid method, should be lower than an eighth-grade level. 5 Yet, studies of informed consent documents have revealed language that is more difficult than these standards. 6,7 As well, studies have reported that subjects may not fully understand or may even misunderstand aspects of the biomedical research in which they are participating. In one study of cancer patients, 90% of respondents said that they were both satisfied with the consent process and fully understood the biomedical research in which they were involved. However, only 26% understood that the biomedical research they were involved in was not a standard treatment process, and only 37% were aware of the potential risks. 8 In addition, many studies have suggested that patients have incomplete or incorrect understanding of information in the consent forms to participate in a clinical trial. 9

In Korea, this problem is even worse. A study was conducted in 5 general hospitals in Korea involving patients older than age 18 and their relatives, as well as hospital workers and biomedical research associates. 10 Of these subjects, 86.1%, 95.3%, and 72.5%, respectively (overall value of 83.2%), affirmed that they had heard about “informed consent.” 10 However, in another study that investigated the understanding of informed consent among healthy volunteers, objective knowledge score was 68.7 points (max: 100 points) and perceived (subjective) understanding was 78.7 points, 11 which were lower than those of a US study 12 and an Australian study 13 that used the same instrument. In addition, the Korean language lacks tools to assess the readability of consent documents, in contrast with the English language, making it impossible to measure the difficulty or readability of terms described in the provided information.

Because of these circumstances in Korea, this study was done to evaluate the subjective understanding of study-related and adverse event–related terms in informed consent forms for biomedical research from patients as potential subjects and from nurses who may care for subjects involved in a biomedical research study.

sec.title: Study Design
sec.p: This was a cross-sectional study to evaluate patients’ and nurses’ exposure to and subjective understanding of technical terms in informed consent forms for biomedical research.

sec.title: Study Participants
sec.p: The participants were patients and nurses who could participate in biomedical research as subjects or research assistants, respectively, in the Republic of Korea. The patients were conveniently recruited in internal medicine or family medicine outpatient clinics of a tertiary referral and teaching hospital in Busan. The nurses worked in the same general wards in which the patients were treated. The nurses’ experience varied from <1 year, 1 to 4 years, and >5 years.

The study was performed after getting approval from the Pusan National University Hospital Institutional Review Board. With permission of the director of the nursing department, 1 research assistant visited the outpatient clinics to conduct questionnaire-based patient interviews. Of the 457 patients who were contacted, 432 completed the questionnaires, representing a 94.5% response rate. Nurses were recruited by the director of the nursing department, who distributed the questionnaires; completed questionnaires were received from 158 nurses. The data were collected in February 2011.

sec.title: Instruments
sec.p: The study instrument was a structured questionnaire developed by the research team in the absence of a valid and reliable instrument. We reviewed several informed consent forms for biomedical research in Korea and selected common but frequently used technical terms: 10 study-related and 10 adverse event–related terms. The questionnaire was checked for content validity by a research team comprising 3 professors of medical and nursing schools who were independent ethics committee members. The final questionnaire had 4 sections: demographics, exposure to the terms, understanding of the terms, and the recognition of certain blood volume.

Gender, age, education, exposure to biomedical research, and career as nurses (nurses only) were included as demographics. The exposure to the terms (eg, “Have you ever heard of each term?”) was measured as 1 = ever or 0 = never, with a total score of 0 to 10. The understanding of the terms (eg, “How much do you know the meaning of the terms?”) was measured on a 3-point scale (1 = don’t know, 2 = know vaguely, 3 = know well), with a total score of 10 to 30. We also categorized responses in 2 groups: know well (3) and don’t know well (1 and 2). The recognition of certain blood volume (eg, “How much is 5 mL of blood volume when you measure it with an adult spoon?”) was based on 4 answers: 1/3 spoon, 1/2 spoon, 1 spoon, and 2 spoons.

sec.title: Data Analyses
sec.p: The collected data were coded and analyzed using SPSS version 18.0 for Windows (SPSS, Inc, an IBM Company, Chicago, Illinois) for frequency and percentage or mean and standard deviation. The t test or analysis of variance test was used to observe the differences in distribution by demographics to the questions “ever exposed to the terms” and “understood the terms well.” The χ 2 test was used to assess the relationship between the proportion of correct answers to the amount of blood (5 mL) and demographics. All statistical tests were performed at the .05 level of significance for 2-tailed tests.

sec.title: General Characteristics of the Subjects
sec.p: The 432 patients had an average age of 52.6 years. Most (64.6%) were women, 48.3% had graduated high school, and 6.0% had never participated in a biomedical research study. Of the 158 nurses, virtually all (99.4%) were women, their average age was 27.0 years, 54.4% had graduated from a 4-year college, the average career span was 4.0 years, and 31.0% had never participated in biomedical research studies as nurses (Table 1).

fn.p: NA, not applicable.
aAge ranges on the left apply to patients; those on the right apply to nurses.
bCombined totals from 3-year college through graduate school.

sec.title: Distribution of Exposure to Each Term
sec.p: Table 2 summarizes the overall proportion of positive responses to exposure to terms in informed consent forms (“ever exposed to the terms”). The percentage of responses ranged from 4.9% to 80.8% for patients and 22.8% to 99.4% for nurses. For patients, the term phase III was the least recognized (4.9%), followed by double blinding (19.0%) and randomization (31.9%). For nurses, the term phase III was also the least recognized (22.8%), followed by double blinding (32.3%) and tolerance of drugs (72.8%).

caption.p: Distribution of Exposure to and Subjectively Perceived Understanding of the Terms

sec.p: The percentage of positive responses to “ever exposed to the adverse event–related terms” ranged from 17.6% to 94.1% for patients; the term palpitation was the least recognized (17.6%), followed by tremor (22.2%) and pruritus (33.5%). For nurses, all terms elicited a recognition rate exceeding 95%.

Tables 3 and 4 summarize the demographic distribution of respondents to whether they were ever exposed to the terms. Patients, on average, recognized 11 terms, but the recognition rate statistically differed by age (P < .001), education (P < .001), and exposure to biomedical research (P = .002). Nurses, on average, recognized 17.5 items, but statistical differences were evident by education (P = .048).

caption.p: Distribution of Exposure to Informed Consent Form Terms Among Patients (n = 427)

fn.p: Data expressed as mean ± standard deviation unless otherwise indicated.
a P value obtained by t test.

tr.th: No. of Adverse Event–Related Terms Exposed

c P value obtained by t test.

sec.title: Distribution of Good Understandability of Each Term
sec.p: The results on the distribution of good understandability of each term are summarized in Table 2. The percentage of positive responses to “understanding of the study-related terms well” ranged from 0.9% to 56.2% for patients and 5.1% to 70.9% for nurses. For patients, the term phase III was the least recognized (0.9%), followed by double blinding (7.5%) and placebo (12.4%). For nurses, the term phase III was also the least recognized (5.1%), followed by double blinding (15.2%) and tolerance of drugs (25.3%). The percentage of “understanding of the adverse event–related terms well” ranged from 9.6% to 83.8% for patients and 72.8% to 93.0% for nurses. For patients, the term palpitation was the least recognized (9.6%), followed by tremor (11.5%) and pruritus (16.2%). For nurses, the term tremor was least understood (72.8%).

Tables 5 and 6 summarize the results of the demographic distribution of respondents to whether they understood the terms well. On average, the patients understood 7.1 terms well; the recognition was statistically different by age group (P < .001), education (P < .001), and exposure to biomedical research (P = .023). On average, nurses understood 13.7 terms well; their recognition displayed statistical differences by education (P = .006) and exposure to biomedical research (P = .006).

caption.p: Distribution of Subjectively Perceived Understanding of the Terms Among Patients (n = 427)

sec.title: Correct Responses Concerning Blood Volume
sec.p: Twenty-nine percent of patients and 10.1% of nurses knew the correct answer concerning blood volume. Both groups tended to overestimate the actual amount (Table 7). Male patients and nurses who had completed a postgraduate course displayed a higher rate of correct response (P = .002 and P = .018, respectively).

caption.p: Recognition of Blood Volume (5 mL) in Spoon

tr.th: Blood Volume of 5 mL Is Equal to:

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, we evaluated the subjective understanding of patients and nurses by selecting terms that are generally used in informed consent documents: 10 common study-related terms, 10 adverse event–related terms, and the recognition of a certain blood volume. Results from the patient group showed that they understood 3 of 10 study-related terms and 4 of 10 terms related to adverse events. However, nurses understood 5 of 10 study-related terms; despite their better understanding of adverse event–related terms, the overall understanding level seemed to be low.

Concerning the term clinical trial/research, both patients and nurses generally had heard the term, but only about 40% of them asked to know the meaning of the term. Of note, only 1% of patients and 5% of nurses were clearly aware of the meaning of the term phase III. Therefore, the investigators should give more detailed explanations to subjects and nurses or research assistants when these terms are used.

Nurses showed a high level of exposure to the term placebo, whereas the patients did not, perhaps reflecting nurses’ job-related experience. The term randomization showed lower and less satisfactory understanding than that of placebo for both patients and nurses. Very few patients had heard and understood the meaning of the term, which is consistent with the results of a previous study conducted in Korea. 11 In some studies, one of the terms the subjects had difficulty understanding was randomization. In fact, many researchers, ranging from 62% 14 to 83%, 15 discussed randomization with subjects during the process of obtaining consent. However, only 17% actually checked to determine whether the patient understood the term, 14 and at most, half the patients could comprehend the term. 15 The use of placebo and randomization is very common in phase III trial/research, where the patients are usually participating. Therefore, there is a great need to provide sufficient explanations, ensure those terms are understood, and, if possible, use alternative and plain-language terms.

Terms that showed a poor level of understanding among the adverse events–related terms were palpitation, tremor, and pruritus. Although palpitation or tremor may not be common to patients, pruritus would be better understood if itching was used instead. On the other hand, we had predicted that nausea, as a common gastrointestinal symptom, would be a very familiar term. However, only 33% of respondents knew the meaning of this word. Considering that the understanding of adverse events–related terms was significantly different between nurses as medical experts and patients, and also being aware that patients should rapidly inform medical experts about those events whenever they happen, it seems that more detailed information should be fully provided when obtaining informed consent.

On the other hand, the understanding of study-related or adverse events–related terms in the patient group was related to age, educational level, and participatory experience in biomedical research. Patients older than age 60 with a middle school or lower education level and no participatory experience in biomedical research showed a lower level of understanding of those terms. Researchers need to recognize these factors when helping subjects understand the diverse terms used in informed consent statements and use various strategies to ensure that subjects are aware of the meaning of the document they sign. Previous analyses of the effects of text, tables, and pictographs on subjects’ understanding reported that pictographs are more effective than the other 2 types of communication. 16,17 Therefore, these methods could also be used and their effectiveness evaluated. For nurses, those having a graduate diploma or higher degrees showed better understanding of study-related terms, perhaps because they had studied research methodologies during their graduate courses.

Concerning the blood volume responses, only 10.1% of nurses and 29.0% of patients responded correctly; most subjects overestimated the volume. This lower rate of understanding by nurses, who would be expected to know the correct volume as they measure out similar volumes with syringes during their daily duties, indicates that there could be a significant difference between the subject’s understanding and their actual meanings. Our experiences with biomedical research have indicated that subjects can be sensitive to the issue of bleeding, especially to the volume of bleeding, throughout the diverse procedures they undergo. Considering themselves as vulnerable patients with disease, they seem to think that bleeding could affect their health and, therefore, may resist blood collection. Knowing this, describing the volume of blood taken in terms such as “a spoonful” and/or the use of pictures may assist and comfort patients.

In this study, by evaluating the understanding levels of patients and nurses about the technical terms generally used in biomedical research, we were able to identify the level of understanding of the technical terms in informed consent forms and determine terms in need of particular attention or better explanation. However, this study was based on subjective responses of subjects. Therefore, this limitation should be considered in understanding our results, and further studies should comparatively analyze subjective and objective understanding levels of these terms. In addition, we also recommend further studies to investigate easier terms than the ones that showed lower understanding in this study.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study aimed to investigate patients’ and nurses’ exposure to and understanding of technical terms used in informed consent forms. Considering the low level of subjects’ understanding of major clinical terms and adverse events–related terms, sufficient explanations should be provided when obtaining informed consent, to make sure subjects understand what they are being told. Use of less technical terms or outright replacement of confusing terms with plain-language explanations could be a prudent strategy. We also suggest that figures or audiovisual media could be fruitfully used in informed consent, instead of currently used text-based forms.

fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
